name: Monte Antiogu Boi LZ
desc: Nearest landing is localized in a clearing area , about 40 meters long, surrounded by shrubbery and trees. I can land with my hang glider, but it is reccommended for experienced pilots only ! The main landindg area is alongside the main road SS125 at 23°Km, in the right side going back to Cagliari. It is a very large area, but if you do not climb the right altitude you can not arrive there, since it is about 2Km far from takeoff

name: Salto -river
desc: by the river (can be seen from launch); 2 windsocks available; WInd normally from SE. Land only in the designated area (> see pix)!

name: Pieve landing
desc: Quite tecnichal spot for landing... Check before fly

name: Spiaggia MEZZA GALERA
desc: Atterraggio sulla spiaggia di Marina di Pisciotta.. Alcune aree della spiaggia presentano ciottoli di grossa dimensione,per cui prestare attenzione. Presenza di turisti ed ombrelloni nel periodo estivo, tuttavia ci sono spazi sufficienti per atterrare alle spalle degli ombrelloni.

name: atterraggio pennino 1
desc: Easy and large. Be aware in strong condition better land on top of the small hill and avoid landing too close to the white road.

name: Atterraggio Macchialunga
desc: Very large and easy.

name: Positano -beach
desc: Positano: Beach: ATTN: VERY crowded in summer!!!

name: San Giuliano Terme LZ
desc:
The landing area is in front of the takeoff. The distance between them is about 1 km. Therefore, it is easily accessible with any type of glider (minimum efficiency 1:2.8). The grass field measures about 80 meters in length and 60 in width, a huge space to use, so the landing is very easy, and it is suitable for all kinds of pilots. The landing area has a wide parking lot. Bars and restaurants just a few meters away.

It gives the opportunity to land approaching from all four directions: north, south, east and west.

However, there are a railway line and an electric power line on both sides of the landing area, It is recommended to pay particular attention to the altitude disposal and landing stages, avoiding potentially dangerous maneuvers. It worth remarking that the landing area sizes allow safe landings for everyone.

San Giuliano Terme area offers several fields that can be used as emergency landing. Please stay out of the private fields and, in case of an off-field landing, move away as quickly as possible without causing damages.

name: Skyline LZ
desc:
restricted landing sites: sporting grounds of UTECH (pilots must check in with Mr M. Henry (876) 817-8068 before flying this site)
 
bail-outs: school yard, and public park (Hope Gardens);

name: John Crow Hill LZ
desc:
Top-landing possible, please respect local vegetable farmers; 
normal LZ on the flats below - Hounslow sports field or cattle land; watch out for barbed wire fences!

name: Freehill LZ
desc: Blenheim Glider port N of launch (not in a glide on a windy day)

name: Pen Hill - Kirkvine LZ
desc:
Option 1: Windalco Sports Club (upwind; closed on weekdays)
Option 2: SW of launch at Windalco Officer's Club
Option 3: top landing

name: Spur Tree South LZ
desc: huge grassy LZ (rehabilitated bauxite mine)

name: Lovers Leap LZ
desc: top landing is advised or if you sink out there is a landable spot at approx. 1'000 ft asl on slope below launch

name: Cabbage Hill LZ
desc: on sports field between road fr Easington to Llandewey and Yallas river or in dry river bed

name: Dana LZ
desc:
Top landing is as easy as having a tea offered by bedouins -which means VERY easy :)-
If you can't land on top, that would mean there is not so much wind, then it is quite ok to land just before the village, there are two small biuldings next to the road, with a clean, flat but small place to land. Careful, this landing at dana village may be in rotors when valley breege is strong, but then you should be able to land on top.

name: Wadi Mujib - South face LZ
desc:
Best is to land on top, easy if you have the altitude for it.
If you have to land down, there is a small place near a track 200m down the viewpoint but it is small and technical. My advice is to go check before flying and find a place that you think is good for you.
(you can also try to go see down in the wadi to the East (to the dam), if you can find a suitable place to land close to the road.)

name: Wadi Mujib - North face LZ
desc: A good easy, not to rocky, place a bit above the track, you'll have to walk back to the track a bit but the landing is comfortable.

name: Beida - South West LZ
desc: Possible landings any place down, we landed close to the road that goes north to the Wadi Araba. Be careful here, we found some 'Venturi' effect apparently due to the hills on the west, wich made the wind direction at landing coming more from north than what we had at launch place.

name: Beida North-West LZ
desc: A big clean field below, but with electrical lines after it. (approximative gps coords given)

name: Palaces road LZ
desc:
On top recommanded, and not to difficult if conditions are not too strong (careful with the road/lights).
Possible to land down rather easily, but you will have to walk the way back up.

name: Disi sand dune LZ
desc: down the dune

name: Wadi bin hammad LZ
desc: Top landing VERY easy and recommanded, you can also land on the road down rather easily

name: Wadi Mujib West / Hidan LZ
desc: Down the valley. Find a good place and give us the exact cordinates...

name: Rally Track LZ
desc: Large area to land at bottom mostly some rocks and larger rocks but mostly flat with some obvious gullies. An area has been cleared near the track before the junction at the bottom, or land in the D shape easily seen. In winter mostly Bedouins in the area as is warmer weather. So try to land away from livestock Goats Camels etc

name: Nakijin LZ
desc: A big, beautiful sandy beach.

name: Kayo LZ
desc: The usual landing is the huge beach to the south of the bluffs, directly in front of the elementary school.  (The oval track in the photo identifies the school.) Top landing at the T/O is also a very viable option.

name: Teniya LZ
desc: The landing is on the beach below.  The beach is only accessible by rugged 4WD vehicle. To walk back to launch takes about 30 minutes.  Alternatively, you can drive about two thirds of the way in a regular car (your pilot will have to walk up the rest of the way). Top landing is possible, but your spot landing skills need to be good.

name: Paraglider Park Aoki LZ
desc:
large LZ with windsocks;
(marked) power line along side road

name: Minakami ('Grand-Volee') LZ
desc: Medium sized landing area a little up the valley. Has practice slopes on the edge and is slightly sloping. Can be very thermic. Approach is figure of eight to the west in the usual southerly flying conditions.

name: Parafield LZ
desc: Landing place is 2. TOP landing is easy.

name: Hakuba -Happo One LZ

name: Mt Itajiki Hangglider Area LZ

name: Uono LZ
desc: huge; can be seen from TO

name: Yatake LZ
desc: can be seen from TO

name: Ohsayama Flight Area (Mt.Osa) LZ

name: Keihoku LZ

name: Nanyo Skypark LZ
desc: flat lawn (150mÃ—100m)

name: Kuratake LZ
desc:
LZ is a shallow rice paddy, about 80x40m.  Winds tend to be steady most of the time.
TOP-landing possible, but not easy!

name: Kirikabu-yama LZ

name: Kannami (eX Paragliding) LZ

name: Ojigatake/ Ojigadake LZ

name: Sky Shishiku LZ

name: Daikanbo LZ

If dropped it is usually possible, if not always easy, to reach a flat landing at the bottom of the crater rim slope, about 2-3km away and 500m lower.  There is also a large cleared slope on the west side, but landing here is tricky and recovery time-consuming.

name: Zojiro LZ

name: imaihama flying school LZ

It's inside a small volcano!
Rough air if it's strong.

name: Takayama East LZ

name: Kanemi-dake LZ

name: Aoshima LZ

name: Okamidake (Ogami) LZ

name: Paratopia (Goryu) LZ

name: main landing

name: Kagamiyama Landing
desc: At the beach

name: Sportsfield

name: Kerio Valley LZ

name: Otres hill LZ
desc: evrywhere down but not on the rice fields when they are  growing !

name: Bokor LZ
desc: At the southern and south-west wind toplending possible. Established landing is near the road to the sea at a distance of about 5 km. the slope. Requires a preview! Along the way, at a different distance, high-voltage wires go!

name: Mt. Jungkwang LZ
desc: Easy.  In the late evening at sunset, you may have to land from the west (opposite direction) due to changing wind direction.

name: Gan Wahl Jae LZ
desc: 150 Meters

name: Am Dahl San LZ
desc: 10m  Nice and large in the winter when the rice fields are cut and dry.

name: Day Am San LZ
desc: Large Soccer Field for landing

name: Yumyungsan LZ
desc:
The landing is a large grassy field. Approach is best made over the trees to the rightas you aproach from the mountain. There is a power line running along the road to the left of the field.
Due to the landing zone being at the convergence of three valleys, the wind frequently shifts and can blow in different directions at the same time. Keep approach speed high.

name: Danyang LZ
desc: There's also a second landing option north east (other side of river, same side of the bridge) of the one that's marked in paraglidingearth.

name: Mt BangJang LZ
desc: free & site

name: Gom Doli LZ
desc: Landing area is limited to the spot shown. The spot is on the west side of valley in open area. Please only land here and not on the rice fields. Walk back to main street 500meter

name: KoJyae BongSan LZ
desc: On beach (Very long) or football pitch

name: Choburi LZ
desc: A smallish field at the bottom of the mountain with some fake turf for the spring and fall when it can get a little muddy.

name: Geoje-si LZ
desc: Dedicated landing area you can see from take off once pointed out.  Its the only area without vegetables or rice.  Area is small so need good restricted land field practice.  Field is partially surrounded by power lines.  For the sake of the inhabitants and yourself avoid.

name: Jil Lae LZ
desc:
535-6 Sinan-ri, Jillye-myeon
Gimhae, Gyeongsangnam-do
35.228361, 128.744247

Dedicated landing area you can see from take off once pointed out. 
Take off must be good as slope is gentle and trees border the area. 
If taking off from alternate launch, you might have to bear left aroud the mountain edge and keep soaring to the left till you see the LZ.
LZ is the 200m long area along the railroad. Area is quite confortable but rocks scattered in the grass make landing tricky, so need good restricted land field practice and adequate flaring. Be aware of Power lines. 
Alternate landing is easy accross the railroad if you can't make it to the official one.

name: SamcheonPo LZ
desc:
North Landing
45-2 Songpo-dong
Sacheon, Gyeongsangnam-do, CorÃ©e du Sud
34.962929, 128.065867

South Landing
66 Siran-dong
Sacheon, Gyeongsangnam-do, CorÃ©e du Sud
34.951972, 128.054008

name: Samsangro LZ
desc:
758 Bongnam-dong
Sacheon, Gyeongsangnam-do, CorÃ©e du Sud
34.950171, 128.094797

Easy landing after harvest

name: Haman LZ
desc:
35.290444, 128.432065

Alternative landing in the adjacent school courtyard

name: Haman 2 LZ
desc:
Landing :
35.290444, 128.432065 
Alternative landing in the adjacent school courtyard

name: Songdo LZ
desc:
Landing Coordinates
35.07588,129.0154503
On beach, beware of sunseakers

name: Beach landing
desc: Large beach when tide is out.  Trail return to launch.

name: Yangbangsan Observatory LZ
desc: Landing between the parking lot and the river. Quite long and easy, but be aware of some poles..

name: Geum Oreum LZ
desc: Big grassy field (see the map).

name: The Cedars - Top takeoff LZ
desc: Very big landing area. Cars are not allowed to use the dirst road to pick-up the passengers, only the shuttle is allowed in.

name: The Cedars - Bekaa side LZ
desc: Very easy landing on a strip by the main road, right where the road makes a 270 degrees turn.

name: Ghosta LZ
desc: very big, next to the sea.

name: Miziara LZ
desc:
Top landing quite easy, not very easy, but quite easy.
The official landing area was planted by its owners therefore the only landing spot is on the isolated road at the bottom of the hill. Watch out for the incoming traffic

name: Faraya - Wardeh LZ
desc: Ask for som place where there are no people skiing.

name: Faraya - Mzar LZ
desc:
A large slightly sloppy field south west of the take off.
This field is also used from times to times as a school slope, which means the ground quality is good for the area !
Careful : the glide to reach the LZ is quite long.

name: Jbeil LZ
desc: on the beach without problem. Top landing can be a fun exercice with right conditions

name: Dedeh LZ
desc:
Top landing possible.
If you have to go land down, don't wait to be too low, because there is a highway and MANY electric cables to fly over !!

name: The Cedars - Soaring ridge LZ
desc: On take-off. Relatively easy.

name: Annaya LZ
desc: Long and narrow, perfectly oriented in the valley breeze.

name: Knuckles LZ
desc:
Landing = 7 22'35.87' N and 80 44'55.74' E

Elevation = 1848 feet

name: Netoniai LZ
desc: landing site at the same site or behind it 50 m. in agricultural field.

name: Leonpolis LZ
desc: Same as take off or on the country road next to it.

name: Gringlay LZ
desc:
49Â° 54.529'N
  6Â° 5.135'E
Elevation 229m

Be careful with strong West wind, turbulences appear.

Emergency landing :
 49Â° 54.758'N
  6Â° 5.259'E

name: Skriveri LZ
desc: The field below (between foot of the hill and the river)

name: Rumbula LZ
desc: Old airfield. Flatland

name: Nid d'Aigle Auberge LZ
desc:
Alt: 60m on the road to takeoff.
AVOID landing in planted fields, as this will jeopardize this site!
There are lots of barren fields around to land in!
Top-landing possible.

Hike-and-fly takes about 40 minutes from the dunes to the launch. From the road to the dunes, cross the main road and head up-slope (avoiding fields) to find a switchback trail that intersects the road up just below the main switchback. Regain the trail at the main switchback and follow it up to the ridge, a few hundred meters south of the launch. the trail reaches a N-S road behind the launch.

name: Idikl
desc:
Safe Landing below in the valley bassin (and walk up across the a gully to the right on a path to the village of Idikel where retrieval from the Tafraout-Agadir road is easy!) or  below Fifilou  at the road before the high voltage lines.
TOP-landing possible, but(very) tricky/ risky with thermal gusts!

name: Aguergour LZ
desc:
alti: around 800 m.
A big flat land.

name: Ait-ourir LZ
desc: in front of the crest, wherever you want.

name: Legzira (the hill) LZ
desc:
You have 2 possibilities :
1/ On the top of the vilage called LEGZIRA BEACH ... just at right of the track... before arriving at the camping car parking....
2/ Directly on the Beach !!! 
And here you NEVER see that !!!
For many people I've met in Morroco - it's the most beautiful beach !

Momo is very cool guy for sleeping and eating local fish !

name: Merzouga Dunes LZ
desc: Everywhere !! it's like a desert !

name: Sidi Ifni LZ
desc: Landing is only at the bottom on the airfield, visible from take off, unless very expert then top landings could be attempted.

name: Tiz'n Test LZ
desc:
top landing quite technical or ... on the slopes below (very rocky)
Better LZ (football field) further down in the valley, can be seen from TO

name: Touflith / Ait Barka LZ
desc:
Down on the flatlands, about 800m lower.
Just about anywhere.  Beware of rocks and thermals may perturbate your approach.
A good choice is by the pathway that leads back to the road through the village.

name: Mzouda LZ
desc:
'official' LZ: soccer field by the river bed; can be seen from launch.
ATTN: 'aggressive' children, do NOT give them any money as it will only get worse!
No wind sock/ streamers! Do not leave any, as the boys will take them away...
But basically you can land anywhere: avoid cultivated fields!

name: Taghazout LZ
desc:
You can land on the earthroad at the entrance of the campsite.
Or you can choose the beach ( verry big )

name: Imsouane LZ
desc:
NOT FOR BEGINNERS
(I'll will add info tomorrow, on 16.05.2014)

name: Mzedra-Est LZ
desc:
Atterrissage technique
Attention Ã  votre finesse

name: Legzira Beach (the beach) LZ
desc: toplanding or the beach

name: Roghi LZ
desc: No landing under takeoff

name: brajici LZ
desc:
beach or car parking area...very difficult landing in july and august as there is no space

other local sites have bigger landing options throughout the year...good from early april to end of october ...sometimes later into november.

name: Buljarica LZ
desc:
if you land in the camp site by the beach permission must be obtained before you fly, beware of some electricity cables and tents!
Large field surrounded by more fields and beach...just behind camp site...or beach if its not too crowded in mid summer.

name: Landing
desc: Landing here

name: Mojkovac LZ
desc: Football pitch in town or many fields along the river.

name: Dizdarica LZ
desc:
-Place name 'Zelenika'
-50m x 100m grass
-Asphalt road

name: Savin kuk LZ
desc: Plains in front of the mountain, lots of alternatives.

name: Stuoc LZ
desc: Village Tepca, Tara river canyon.

name: Krnovo LZ
desc: -2000m x 500m no obstacles grass field

name: Jejavica LZ
desc: wide variety of fields for landing, with no major risk

name: Balj LZ
desc: Many suitable field next to the river, which is located at the foot of the mountain.738m

name: Visitor LZ
desc: Many fields around lake.

name: Kotor paragliding landing
desc: Lending here)

name: Krusevo LZ
desc: huge flatlands, anywhere, need a driver to pick up, public transport slow and scarse and not to the lauch. dont land in planted fields, dont destroy crops. with dedicated driver, 5 and more flight a day, easy! record is 11 take offs in one day!

name: Ohrid LZ
desc:
Landing on the beach of the camping is prohibited (it was used as a landing zone some time ago). Commonly an area south of the camp is used.
You may also consider landing the dirt road connected to the main road near Trpejca.
Toplanding is also possible.

name: Ribnik LZ
desc: All over at the bottom.

name: Sliva LZ
desc: Faces the flatlands of Pelagonia, everywhere.

name: Bogoslovec LZ
desc: At the bottom there are many flat fields where you can land.

name: Mt. Bogd Khan LZ
desc: This LZ is huge and 100% reachable from the launch site. There are still some houses, fences and electric wires which are somehow close.

name: Cheoc-Van Beach LZ
desc: only the beach, note that the area of beach ground will be influence by tidal, so suggesting have good landing skill

name: Top of the world LZ
desc: either top landing adjacent to takeoff or landing on fields below. always avoid landing in cultivated fields!!

name: Mtahleb LZ
desc:
In the fields below IF THEY ARE NOT CULTIVATED, otherwise you must not land in the ones that have been planted.
Also you can top-land behind the road(behind the takeoff)

name: Pyramid LZ
desc: On the north side of La Gaulette there is new area for building with roads, it is perfect for landing, but beware of the area between the takeoff and the landing since it is has a fence around and you may result in some walking and fence hopping:).

name: Cielo Mágico
desc: Aterrizaje oficial Cielo Mágico

name: Valle de Bravo - La Torre LZ
desc: Santa Maria LZ

name: Fortin de las Flores LZ
desc: the town is Coapichapan and is SE from the take off. 900 m. asl

name: La Salina LZ
desc:
Dirt/sand area. Watch for prickly cactus on perimeter of the LZ.

If you get some height over the ridge, you can go land at the beach and have a beer at 
http://www.bajabrent.com

name: Cabanas Piano
desc:
The Cabanas (Cabins) Piano LZ is located to the left below a clearing North of 3 cabins. This LZ is NOT recommended for mid-day flights, due to a thermal trigger below Launch.
The Road Piano LZ is below Launch to the right and runs North-South to the village below. 
 
There are trials from both LZs backup to Launch; these can be walked in less than 40 minutes. The Cabanas LZ trail is located to the right of the fence.  It follows the ridgeline uphill, then heads to the right, above the cows and water holding pool.

name: Malinalco LZ
desc: There are a number of open agracultural fields at the base of launch, any which one that is not planted should be suitable for landing.  The one place you should NOT land is in the country club at the base of launch, as your wing will be confiscated if you land there.

name: Yelapa Tapita LZ
desc: Long sandy beach with lagoon on backside, bars & restaurants & sunbathers on beach.

name: Yelapa Tapa LZ
desc: Long sandy beach with lagoon on backside, bars & restaurants & sunbathers on beach. Same LZ as for Yelapa Tapita.

name: El Piano Africa
desc: The official landing is a big grass field 2.5km in front of the launch. The favorite cross country flight is in the direction of Valle de Bravo, to land on the lakeside landing of Santa Maria, 14km to the NNW.

name: La Ceja Tapalpa LZ
desc:
Valley or Top Land LZ
If sled ride to the valley, retrieval needed or bus transportation required to come back to launch

name: Zaachila LZ
desc: The oficial is heading to the east folowing the road, where we came from, to the left side and before the Power lines, ther is a big field for landing. If you are high enogh to cross the powerlines go wherever you want.

name: Loma Maria LZ
desc: El paraiso, is next to a river with fresh and very clean water; perfect for a splash after landing. Believe me YOU WILL LOVE IT.

name: Vergel de la Sierra LZ
desc:
Option:
1.- 1,100 ft. down the take off
2.- On the take off
3.- At a near Golf Course
4.- XC

name: Safari
desc: Aterrizaje Oficial de Nogalera

name: Despegue Bistro LZ
desc: Lots of free fields to land, with one easy to reach in any conditions and with retrievals, very near to the road.

name: cantil de las aguilas LZ
desc: Enough fields for landing down the take off, for very suitable for toplanding as well.

name: Teta Azul de la Misión LZ
desc:
The LZ is access via a gravel road just 2 or 3 minutes past the turnoff to the antenna. Again, this is two wheel drive accessible and will get your vehicle to with 200 feet of the beach. The parking area is also the best landing area and there is plenty of room for both. Landing on the beach either near the parking area or closer to the antenna is a good option although you will need to make a crosswind final with a very short turn into the wind right before touchdown.

If you leave the mountain within 100 feet of launch, you should have no problem making it to the parking area LZ. If you scratch down lower then a bailout beach landing will be required with a five minute walk back to the parking area.

name: Alto Lucero LZ
desc: Known as 'los Huajes' very close to Take off mountain. less than 2 km away from mountain. you can see it fron the take off. next to th LZ there use to be a little circular lake.

name: Concha Chinas LZ
desc: You will be landing on the beach.  While there is a beach below launch, the hotel there is not very pilot friendly.  It is better to land on the beach at:  20Â° 36' 21.38' N 105Â° 14' 17.46 W.  You will need to crab your landing a bit, land on the beach dodging people and then if your spot landing is good, you will not get wet and your wing will land on the dry sand.  You should be able to make this LZ if you leave the flying area at the launch altitude.

name: Tulancingo LZ
desc: Landing near gas station but mostly top landing.

name: Tulum LZ
desc: On the public beach (BE CAREFULL with the people, the sea and the rocks...)

name: Boca Paila Dune LZ
desc: Landing on the beach

name: Lago Seco San Marcos LZ
desc:
Dry lake landing zone, no obstacles 
Landing just in front of the Take off and 500 mts. below
There is an aero club in the landing zone with hangars to keep the equipment there if need it
20.3497778 N and 103.5588611 W and 1350 mts. ASL

name: Tepoztlan LZ
desc:
Located beside the football field in Santo Domingo, Tepoztlan. Usually the approach and landing is East - SouthEast bound.

Mind the electricity lines and houses sorroundind the landing field. You can often find some air bubbles and lift as you approach landing. Be prepared to spend some time over the approach before loosing altitude.

name: Hill
desc: On the foot of the hill, where it is less steep

name: Bukit Jugra, Banting LZ
desc: Good large area landing zone below.

name: Bukit Dangdut, Seremban LZ
desc: 02 football size agriculture field to choose

name: Ruhiang Hill Tamparuli LZ
desc:
The landing site will be at the flat land near
Cultural House.

name: Gunung Ledang LZ
desc: Landing area use to be at GPS Coordinate N2 20.459 E102 38.311 ASL 70 Meters. but this may have changed now.

name: Cameron Highlands LZ
desc: School football field below. Landing approach usually from North or NNE and can often be with some tail wind. Its possible to land on the tea plantation roads if your careful

name: Bukit Ramli LZ
desc: Along side the main road, there's a suitable place for LZ or need site clearance on the middle way down.

name: Kg. Lohan, Ranau LZ
desc: hard stone surface, beside stony river.. in the progress for upgrade

name: Lambayan LZ
desc: top land is possible..or just land at the beach

name: Mount Kinabalu South Peak LZ
desc:
1. Kundasang Village road site
2. Mesilau Golf Resort

name: Hijauan Heights, Pedas LZ
desc: The LZ is situated at 350ft ASL, an open space about 500m from the TO. There are shades and a lake at LZ with public amenities and parking space.

name: Kuala Kubu Bharu LZ
desc: Designated LZ is an open stadium located 1.8km in straight line-of-sight from TO at approximate 120ft ASL. Straight-line flight path takes about 10 minutes if without catching any thermals. Plenty of boom-out areas at the football fields nearby or plain grass areas next to the ponds and river.

name: Gunung Jerai LZ
desc:
The LZ is located 3.5km away from TO and next to a restaurant/face with a shelter to keep the equipment while waiting for the retrieve vehicle.

Driving distance from the LZ to TO is 15 minutes.

name: Bukit Bidong LZ
desc: Landing Zone is an empty field about 300m from the TO and accessible by car.

name: Tiogon Hill LZ
desc:
N 5 25.759
E 116 10.106
ALTITUDE 369M ASL
FOOTBALL FIELD

name: Bukit Genting LZ
desc: Landing is available at paddy fields during dry season or at the walkways in between the paddy fields at any other times. Distance from TO to the nearest LZ is 1.4km in straight line.

name: Bukit Bubus LZ
desc: LZ is the wide beach area situated right next to the hill, you won't miss it and there's plenty of space even for the most conservative pilots.

name: Gunung Raya LZ
desc: The mountain is facing a huge area of paddy fields, a few locations has been designated as the official landing zone although during dry season it is possibel to land just about anywhere.

name: Morongulu beach dune LZ
desc: Land on the beach below

name: Spreets Hoogte LZ
desc: As far as you can go, as long as it is near a road.

name: Vogelberg LZ
desc: Anywhere in the desert around.

name: Ouen Toro LZ
desc: At the top or in the valley on the west side of the take off. Eventualy on the parking lot in front of the site.

name: Dumbea golf field
desc: At the bottom of the mountain (or if necessary landing on the northern limits of the golf course is also tolerated.)

name: Kuendu Beach LZ
desc: A large grass field just down the take off.

name: Mont Dore LZ
desc: In a large grass field at a glide ratio of 4 from take off, or just down the take off to the south in a field with horses.

name: Gadji LZ
desc: In the field down the take off, at a glide ratio of 1.

name: Ga Kaleon LZ
desc: On the sport field at the south entrance of the village.

name: Landing
desc: Take care of the cactus...

name: Hooghalen LZ
desc: landing on the same spot

name: Eiland van Maurik LZ
desc: same field

name: BVG Halle LZ
desc: Road is Molenweg, place is Halle, area is Gelderland.

name: BVG Halle Noord LZ
desc: Road is Aaltenseweg, place is Halle, area is Gelderland.

name: Nieuwvliet  Aerodrome LZ
desc: Aerodrome.

name: Wijk aan Zee LZ
desc: You can land anywhere on the beach but you need to watch out for other beach guests. Near the entry points to the beach it is too crowded and disturbing the other beach visitors will give trouble.

name: Zoutelande LZ
desc: Landing is only allowed between what is called a 'Strandhoofd', in this case the most Northerly Strandhoofd is number 39.1 and most Southerly is 37. Land only between these 'Strandhoofd' (a Strandhoofd is line of wooden stakes running into the ocean for erosion control - the Info board is more clear on this)

name: Plus4 LZ
desc: Details will be submitted soon

name: Bruinehaar LZ
desc: The landing is on the same flatland, a huge grass plane owned by some farmers.

name: Giethoorn LZ
desc: landing on the same spot

name: Petten LZ
desc: Landing is on the same terms and place where you takeoff.

name: Cadzand-bad LZ
desc: At the beach.

name: Nedereindseplas LZ
desc: 0m

name: Eurofly Stegeren LZ
desc: Same as the start.

name: Sollifjellet LZ
desc: Big

name: KilhusaiÂ¿Â½sen LZ
desc: Large landing infront.

name: Bærum- Solfjellstua LZ
desc: On the road beside the field just below the start.

name: Gol - Flatagrov LZ
desc: - You may not drive onto the landing site

name: Sundvollen LZ
desc:
Landing is now open even in summer. Follow local rules on takeoff.

Landing at the school is not allowed out of safety precautions for the students.

Parking is only allowed for picking up.

name: Grefsenkollen LZ
desc: The landing is located to the right if you look down from takeoff. It is a football place. There is no wind indicator installed there.

name: Forbord LZ
desc: Field, all directions

name: Fleineskollen LZ
desc:
Several landing locations. Watch out for power cables.
Top landing almost everywhere on the mountain.

name: Storheia LZ
desc: Large areas for landing south and north.

name: Nedalsklompen LZ
desc: Road. parkingspot, wetlands...

name: Hanguren LZ
desc: next to the lake, wherever convenient (check the panel next to the little chalet by the lake next to Park hotel

name: Kvitegga LZ
desc: Huge landing by the gas station.

name: Meråker LZ
desc: LZ on big grasfield on the south side of main road E14, just behind closed cafÃ¨. Look for streamers. Watch out for high voltage power lines.

name: Rye (Trondheim) LZ
desc: On a grassfield beside the old main road. Look for streamers.

name: Tveitane
desc: Landing is a big grass field. When the grass is high, try to land in the middle of the field close to the road. Pack the wing at the side of the field.

name: Byrkjeflot - Lofthus LZ
desc: Landing is a big grass field. When the grass is high, try to land in the middle of the field close to the road. Pack the wing at the side of the field.

name: Nesna Middagstuva Landing
desc: Landingsplassen på Nesna

name: Melås in Gjerstad LZ
desc: Easy an viewable from takeoff

name: Asker- Kraakholmen LZ
desc: Good landing skills required for landing on the small island. Lifejackets required and are lent out. Several alternative landing areas on the mainland. No problem!

name: Nicostarten LZ
desc:
The regular landing is on the field to the left of the takeoff. It is not visible from the takeoff, but will come in view just a few meters out in the air. The field has a tractor path in the middle of it. 

Landing should only happen on the tractor path, and packing must be done on the path.

Please contact the local club for more information on which field it is if in doubt.

Walk down the road towards the farm, turn right up the field and walk towards the radio antenna. Close the gate! Follow the path. The takeoff is behind the radio antenna to the right.

name: Berge LZ
desc: On field below takeoff. Make sure you know the right field before takeoff.

name: Lensamansstarten LZ
desc: The landing is the football field in Ã…rdal. Make sure it isn't in use before going up. Hanggliders have other fields they land on, please contact the local club for more information

name: Nuten LZ
desc: Landing on the field below start, in front of the houses. The houses will create some turbulence.

name: Kløve - Øvre Eidfjord LZ
desc: By the camping.

name: Hjelle LZ
desc:
Next to the lake. 
Watch out for the power lines crossing the field.

name: Bjellandsfjellet LZ
desc: There is a marked trail (red streamers) up the mountain. One must go, and the trip takes about 35-40 minutes. Landing is down at the slaughterhouse. If you need more space for landing, you can land outside the landing area on one of the outlying fields.

name: Dalsnuten LZ
desc:
The landing is at Dale, or by water along the trail on the way up.

Picture shows Dalsnuten on the left, landing is in the corner field at the bottom of ridge (end of the fields by the buildings, you can just see gravel car park to the right of the end field amongst the trees) - note that the Dale area is being developet so check area before flying.

name: Sauebeite
desc: Landing må avklares med grunneier på forhånd

name: Kvåle Stadion
desc: Vær oppmerksom på aktivitet på banen

name: Main landing
desc: Det er etablert landing i Loen, se bilde. Bruk området som er merket "Hovedlanding". Bufferområde merket "Reserve-/nødlanding" brukes dersom nødvendig. I vekstsesongen er det viktig å unngå unødvendig tråkk i enga, ta med utstyret til veikanten for pakking. Biler skal parkeres på det oppmerkede området, bruk parkeringsplasser lenger vest dersom behov for flere plasser. Vindpølse er montert på "Hovedlanding", i tillegg er det vanligvis flagg i området ved Hotel Alexandra og Hotel Loenfjord. Var observant på flaggene i dalen, och räkna med en god del sjunk i luften ifall de står ens lite från berget.

name: Bjørndalen
desc: Landing zones are almost everywhere on a nearby bog. If landing at Bleik please land on the beach or on the fields. DO NOT LAND ON THE GOLF COURSE OR NEARBY THE GRAVEYARD.

name: Umskardet
desc: At the parking 630 m

name: Rana, Snøfjellet Landing
desc: The landing is beside the parking on cropland. There is no deal with the farmer so be careful and not pull down grass.

name: Rana Kubben Landing
desc: Landing is just a few meters from the parking

name: Rana, Mofjellet Vest landing
desc: Landing at Statens Innkrevingssentral

name: Arnipa LZ
desc: Landing can be done on all the bogs and fields, but stay away from the cabins in the area. The locals are maintaining the road out to the mountain so we don't want to disturb them. Also be aware of sheep and wet landings...

name: Sokn Airfield LZ
desc: All directions

name: Mjelle
desc: Landing på parkeringen eller ved jordet ved siden av. Vær obs på lavspentledninger som går over veien.

name: Sarangkot LZ
desc:
There are 4 landing places along Phewa lake shore, from Phokara to the end of the lake, perfect to play and acro training.
Avoid the landing by Lakside Pokhara when it's windy, as it gets rotor form the buildings
The safest is the one by the end of the lake as it's always smooth air.

Wind at landing can change its direction very abruptly. Observe well the windsock while still at altitude.

desc:
By the living Spring road turn off. Private property, farm beside. Thank the guy. Watch the power line all around the field. plus its a bit slopy. Bit technical.
Better to do a slope landing close to the top or a top landing beside the rock pile with a wind sock on it.
Best hang gliding landing is on the north of the Teddington straights.  Power lines run along the road.
Another great place to land is in the paddock beside the Wheatsheif Tavern in Teddington.

name: Moirs Hill LZ
desc:
Landing requires careful consideration being in a valley with the wind usually coming from one end or the other. An aircraft type landing circuit approach is strongly recommended to determine the wind direction in the bottom of the valley (often different from the wind on launch).

Top landing on takeoff is possible although very tight for hang gliders and often quite thermic posing difficulty for paragliders. An alternative top landing is available to the north east of the transmitter tower requiring a minimum of 600ft above takeoff before making an approach.

Top landing at any point should only be attempted by those experienced in top landing.

desc: Landing zone is on the beach in front of takeoff and is large, especially at low tide.

name: Karioitahi A LZ
desc: When landing on the beach keep look out for beach traffic particularly through summer and when the tide is high. There is a 'no landing zone' that extends roughly 50 m north and south of the grassy derigging area in front of the bottom carpark. Please do your best to avoid landing close to the grassy derigging area when there are lots of other beach users about. Keep an eye out for vehicles and hoons on bikes before setting up for a landing.

There is a 'no landing zone' that extends roughly 50 m north and south of the grassy derigging area in front of the bottom carpark. Please do your best to avoid landing close to the grassy derigging area when there are lots of other beach users about. Keep an eye out for vehicles and hoons on bikes before setting up for a landing.

name: Landing
desc:
Normal landing area is between the tall Norfolk Pine and the beach. You can land anywhere in the dunes or further out on the beach. The dune area is not flat, so take care.

Take extra care in high season (December-February) when the campground is full. Always land with ample clearance of any tents, caravans, trees, and people. Remember; not everybody thinks we are in full control, so just stay away to avoid any misunderstandings.

When in doubt, land on the beach. It's only a 150 meter walk back to the campground where you can pack your wing on the grass.

Top landing is possible, but for expert pilots only:

When the wind direction is N - NNW; fly to the very end of the ridge, towards the swimming pool. Turn and fly towards the back ridge of the take-off (your approach to the take-off is from the west). If too low (at any time); bail out and fly to the front of the hill to try again. If too high, make figure-8 turns above the back (S) ridge of the take-off until you are low enough to top-land into wind. Turbulence in this wind direction is minimal, as long as you don't go too far back (never cross the fence that runs along the walking path south of the take-off)

When the wind is coming more from the WNW - NW; from the spur (just before the bowl), fly straight out towards the ocean. Keep looking back towards the hill and turn back until you are at the right height to fly over the highest tree on the ridge with a meter or so (your approach to the take-off is from the NE). Once you are over the tree on the ridge, it will get quite turbulent for a bit until you connect with the back of the take-off. If you are too high (you normally are); make figure-8's until you are low enough to land into wind on the top. 

This latter option is the more turbulent route, but you can't come in from the west anymore because you will be flying with the wind towards the take-off at too high speed to make a safe top-landing.

name: Miraflores LZ
desc:
Landing is back on top at the take-off point. If it is suitable for flying then the lift is normally good just when you want to land. The landing is difficult for the inexperienced as you cannot get down fast enough and the landing is small. It is very common here to use 'big-ears' right up until landing. (see YouTube video). You should never fly behind the back wall of the landing area as there can be rotor in stronger winds and there are lamp posts and trees.

If you have to land down on the beach you should get as far right or left from the launch as you can as the beach is wider there. Landing in front of launch is not advisable due to the thin beach, power lines and lamp posts.

Nevertheless, be carefull because there is another landing place, closer to the take off, where the owner hates the pilots land on their field and could be dangerouse. 
Watch out for mountain bikers!

Itâ€™s a huge green area just next to the military quarters.  Try to avoid aproximities above the military, they get pissed sometimes.  Itâ€™s situated at an altitude of 2900 m thatâ€™s 600 m lower than take-off. Just be careful with the power line and make sure you have enough altitude to get there. Leave the landing through the north-gate and take a right to the road. From there you can get a cab back to town.

You'll come to an macadam road, and after about 200m you'll see the wind socket.

name: Balsamar LZ
desc:
Both CDI (Balsamar)and Izcacuyo beaches are proper to land when the tide is at least halfway out. Be sure to check your tides to be on the proper timeframes.  Izcacuyo, although shorter and more technical, is most immediate to the launch, if a great deal of altitude is lost at the start, it is recommended to land here.

Both landings are privately owned.  Please contact  â€œLos Zopilotosâ€ to ensure a better experience.

*landing* : 1- CDI 850 mts              13Â°30'3.3'N; 89Â°32'435.5'W - Elevation : 0m
                   
2 -   Izcacuyo 662mts     13Â°29'46.96'N; 89Â°31'49.43'W - Elevation : 0 m

name: k 51 LZ
desc:
13Â°39'35.04'N; 88Â°50'8.14'O â€“ Elevation: 540 m
Both the take off and the landings are easily accessible and well maintained year-round by â€œLos Zopilotosâ€.  There is a dirt road which is a 5-8 minute drive down to the river (landing), so a high vehicle or SUV is most proper to use for pilot recovery.

name: Coatepeque LZ
desc:
GPS: 13Â°53'10.31'N; 89Â°31'39.26'W 
Elevation : 746 m
The best field to land is located about 1400 mts to the right of the takeoff if facing the lake.  It is around 110 mts long, kind of short.  It is located paralel to the beach and it has a peculiar rock that makes it easy to distinguish.  You usually land sideways to the wind.  Walk around 5 minutes back to the road for recovery.

desc:
One big, obvious open schoolyard that is within an easy glide from 100m below launch so if you drop low just pull out. (you'll be greeted by anout 200-300 school kids and locals)

A couple of smaller bailing zones on the way to the school yard.

name: Marshall (San Bernardino) LZ
desc:
Marshall has a superb and well maintained LZ in the Andy Jackson Airpark, which was constructed to be level. Defined landing patterns keep hang gliders and paragliders separate on busy days. There is a structure that provides shade and many chairs. There is a large grassy area for folding and breaking down. Limited camping and RV parking is available for nominal fees. No hookups, just a portajohn. 
Andy Jackson Airpark is the only location (in the valley) where it is legal for pilots to land. The City of San Bernardino has an ordinance against flying or landing within city limits and the police can issue tickets to violators.
Picture of the LZ (2002) by Jerome Daoust:
http://www.expandingknowledge.com/Jerome/PG/Site/Marshall/Image/Full/2002_09_14_CA_Marshall_LandingZone.jpg

name: Woodrat Mountain LZ
desc:
Hunter LZ (Hunter Ranch): 42.2471, -123.026 (42°14’49” N, 123°1’33” W); Elevation: 1650 ft. (503 m.); GR: 4.0 from both launches. ||

Longsword LZ (Longsword Vineyard): 42.2328, -123.0553 (42°13’57.88″N, 123° 3’18.93″W); Elevation: 1460 ft. (445 m.); GR: 6.0 from top launch. ||

The Hunter Ranch owners have allowed gliders to land in their cow pasture for the past 30 years, all they ask is that we follow a few simple rules:
• Only current RVHPA members are granted permission to use the Hunter LZ
• Be sure to land only in the currently designated field (which changes from time to time–be sure to have the latest info).
• Observe all Woodrat flying site rules & USHPA regulations.
• No smoking & no alcohol on the LZ.
• No dogs on the LZ.
• No littering. Please pick up any litter you see.
• No kiting, practicing, or instruction in the LZ.
• PG: Please deflate your wing immediately after landing and carry it to the designated fold-up area.
• HG: Please immediately after landing carry your glider to the designated fold-up area.
• Enter and exit the LZ at the access gate in the lower NW corner of the main field.
• Pack up quickly, leave the field, and do not loiter on the Hunter Ranch, parking area, or Bishop Creek Road.
• Keep all gates closed and latched at ALL times.
• No vehicles inside any gated area or in the LZ field.
• Avoid walking by or lingering at the cattle chute between the main field and the feed lot.
• No acro above or near the LZ.
• No powered aircraft within earshot of the LZ.
• “Speed” or “mini” wings are not permitted to use the Hunter LZ due to concerns on their glide ratio relative to a safe glide from launch to the landing area.

Not following the above rules could result in loss of this landing zone.

name: Day Dreams LZ
desc: The Kings Beach landing site has been closed by the North Tahoe Public Utilities District. Please land at Secline Beach (behind the Transam Gas Station) or in a pinch, land at the main beach below the high water-line, near the water's edge. This is the invisible, but very important property line.Please drop your wing immediately and walk up to the sidewalk to fold up. You run the risk of attracting the local police or the State Parks Ranger if you don't follow these new rules.

name: River Delta LZ
desc:
The Wallowa River Delta landing zone is located on Division of State Lands property where the Wallowa River enters Wallowa Lake. We must land in this river delta area and not on the grassy State Park property. Please contact the ECPC before flying from Mt. Howard to arrange paperwork, site intro, and a time when club members are available. 

· This Delta area changes throughout the season, and from year to year. Please plan your flying trips to Mt. Howard accordingly. Contact the local pilots for updates on the delta landing, as it typically doesn’t become large enough for P-4 pilots until mid August. The river normally reaches full volume during the snow melt and spring runoff (Mid June-Mid July). Take high precaution when landing next to the swollen river at this time, as the only possible landing area is very small, rocky, brushy, and surrounded by tall trees!  The swift water could be very dangerous if a wing or a person falls into it!  Usually starting in may, the spring runoff will start to fill the lake as water is held behind the 27-foot tall irrigation dam located at the lake outlet. The lake will continue to fill for most of May, June, and early July until irrigation demands exceed spring runoff flows. Maximum capacity (highest water level) during normal years is around July 15th. After that point, the lake will continue to drop until a huge landing area is exposed by the end of September. 

· Landing a hang glider here is normally not recommended. 

· All pilots are advised to walk through the landing zone and become familiar with the area. Remember, landing zones always seem large from the ground and much smaller from the air!  Most visiting pilots overshoot their landings due to the thinner air and light wind. 

· When the lake is at a higher level (normally mid June-mid July) paraglider landings are not recommended at the lake as the landing area becomes restricted to a very small area with tall trees and a fast flowing river as hazards. Not until August does this landing area normally become easier (not requiring advanced maneuvering skills). It is advised that the river delta landing area be restricted to advanced P4 pilots until mid August when water levels drop and landing becomes more forgiving.

· Do not land on State Park Property! The Wallowa Lake State Park has warned paraglider pilots not to land west of the river delta as it is not an appropriate activity for the park. Please respect the State Park requests and only land in the river delta area!  If the lake is high and the delta landing is too small, go land in the cow pasture or on the east moraine.

At this time, there are no landing options where we have explicit permission to land down in the valley.

The LZ is also not visible from Launch but an ok glide with todayâ€™s gliders.
Definitely check out the cross roads LZ while you are there and make a waypoint in your GPS for easy bearings once up on launch.

If you are not comfortable with the LZ or confident that you can land there, simply offer to drive!

Landing at the Cross-Roads LZ requires solid Intermediate (P3) approach and non-coastal spot landing skills.

name: LZ
desc: Standing at  launch facing north you can't see the LZ.  USHPA recommends that P2 pilots launch with visual contact of the LZ. You must cross power lines to land in the LZ.  The wind patterns on the pond below can help you judge wind cycles & direction. You can also see a wind sock at the east bailout LZ to the right across the road (northeast).

name: Blanchard LZ
desc:
The LZ is private property, but the owner has given permission to land there, except when the hay is tall and ready to cut.  Please be sensitive to the concerns of this property owner, which means:  don't block the driveway, stay away from the house (no fly-overs), don't block the road, and don't bother the neighbors.  Keep the number of parked cars to a minimum.  There is additional parking along the road near the organic garden a quarter of a mile --at the first intersection--to the south.  If you were to upset this very gracious property owner, you would also incur the wrath of many pilots.  If you have to bail-out in any of the other fields, we do not have permission, so bunch up your gear and get out of there as quietly as possible.  Beware of crisscrossing power lines to the various farmhouses. 
Â©nwparagliding.com

If you overshoot, it drops down, and you'll probably end up in the trees. There is a Barb Wire fence that keeps you from coming in low.

Huge open cow fields below launch:
Bail out LZ is HUGE and slightly uphill and can be a very fast no wind landing. Land there and hike out. Hiking out is not bad ..as it is along a dirt road. You will have to take your boots off to cross a shallow stream. Farmers are friendly.

name: Crestline (San Bernardino) LZ
desc:
Same landing as for Marshall. A superb and well maintained LZ in the Andy Jackson Airpark, which was constructed to be level. Defined landing patterns keep hang gliders and paragliders separate on busy days. There is a structure that provides shade and many chairs. There is a large grassy area for folding and breaking down. Limited camping and RV parking is available for nominal fees. No hookups, just a portajohn. 

You can find pictures of the current LZ at the bottom of this page:
http://www.flytandem.com/airpark.htm

Andy Jackson Airpark is the only location (in the valley) where it is legal for pilots to land. The City of San Bernardino has an ordinance against flying or landing within city limits and the police can issue tickets to violators.

name: Dry Canyon LZ
desc:
The LZ is a large flat mown grass field free of any obstructions (the best in the state!). 105Â°56'43.22'W x  32Â°55'42.17'N. It is located somewhat in the town and is visible from the HG launch. The glide ratio to get there from the takeoff is large: without any lift, PGs are unlikely to make it. It is recommended to leave the ridge and go for the LZ as soon as you drop below the first rock band. BEWARE OF HELICOPTERS FLYING LOW AND OVER THE LZ FROM/TO THE HOSPITAL.

If you can't reach the main LZ, paragliders can safely land almost anywhere out in front of launch. The best bailout for PGs is the dirt road that runs SW to NE for a mile or so in way below and in front of launch (it is easily visible from launch). Another great option is a dirt road next to red roofed apartments and allows easy retrieval along Scenic Dr.

Hang glider pilots should always land at the LZ!

name: Mt Graylock LZ
desc: Landing: the bailout LZ is located about 2000ft below launch with about a 2:1 glide. Be attentive to wind and obstacles while setting up your approach. The field is surrounded by tall trees and power lines. Hang gliders may need all of its length. You can break down or fold up in the shade of the big tree on top of the small hill. The main landing zone is not visible from launch due to another mountain obstructing the view. It is about 3000ft lower than launch located about 4 miles northeast just off of Route 8 at The Range. The Range is a golf driving range which also has miniature golf and batting cages. Before landing and still about 500ft above the LZ, yell down to let everyone know you are about to land. They will stop hitting golf balls to allow you room to land. Try to land off to the side if possible. If you need to land in the middle of the field, then do so and put safety first. As soon as you land, pick up your glider and carry it off to the side quickly so The Range customers can go back to hitting their golf balls. You can break down and fold up your glider under the building. The Range does sell cold soda and ice cream.

name: New Jack City - East Ridge LZ
desc:
If you manage to soar the ridge I would recommend flying to the very North end where it intersects the road coming into New Jack City.  Lots of sandy areas here and clean air flow.  If you have enough height, try to tack in a bit East from the ridge and you can hit up some road intersections where you will more room to lower your wing cleanly rather than tagging some brush.

If you sink out right from the start of launch there are a few sandy areas that 'look' free of plants and cacti, those are what you should aim for.  In this case I would recommend killing your glider with a 90 degree turn to get it to all lay down in one clean line.

Could be interesting to fly back over the ridge and land where the camping is, but I imagine the rotor is something nasty and there is lots of broken glass around.  Not recommended unless you are an expert pilot with full understanding of lee-side landings.

name: New Jack City - West Ridge LZ
desc:
The launch is in a bit of a venturi so you will get stronger winds, more gusts and a less accurate wind direction when on launch.

East Launch:  Land in the big camping area by the outhouse.  There's lots of sand, gravel and no plants.

West Launch:  If you sink out just land on the road at the bottom of the hill and have fun with that hike back up ;)  There may be other landing areas further South/North if you manage to soar the ridge.

name: Lake Isabella LZ
desc: Anywhere along the beach.  I ended up landing East of launch near a little picnic area, but you could easily land out front of launch.  About a 10 to 20 minute walk back to the car depending on where you parked.

name: Kernville Slabs LZ
desc:
*** IMPORTANT *** You should be very comfortable with your spot landings to fly here.  Just South of the campground is a small 7m x 7m concrete slab that has some high brush/trees on one side and smaller stuff on the other side.  This is your best bet but it is super tight.  That being said, I'm not a fantastic spot lander and I nailed it my first time so there's nothing overly tricky about it but if you screw up you will be in the trees or pulling your wing out bushes for the next hour.

The landing was right by our campsite so that's pretty awesome.  Although there are campgrounds all around here so your results may vary.

Please watch out for power lines while landing.  Remember to always cross going over the pole not the middle of the wire.

name: Heavener SSE Launch LZ
desc: Large Landing Zone at base of southeast launch.

name: Bellyache Ridge LZ
desc: The landing site and tandem passenger meeting area and directions are available from Google Maps following the link from our website.

name: Kiting Park (Las Vegas) LZ

name: Roan (Rifle) LZ

desc: Primary LZ is next to the road to launch, about 1 mile from launch at 7500ft below launch. Almost the whole San Luis valley is landable, making outlandings easy.

name: Atlanta Paragliding Enterprises (APE) LZ

name: Henninger Flats - No Safe Local LZ LZ
desc:
Wash is in bad shape and all other areas are private property.

Land in the wash below, the further out from the canyon you fly the sandier and more open it gets.  I've found that doing figure eights at the far end of the wash where it turns to run into the dam area (over the high transmission lines) works well then you have plenty of options for a final leg.  This works best for West wind days, south days may be trickier.  Since the wash is below the house line there will be a gradient and expect lots of sink in the last 20' - 30'.

Also make sure to know where the water is flowing in advance sometimes it's not always clear from the air.  Do not land at any of the playing fields in Altadena as that is strictly prohibited.

name: Section 16 LZ
desc:
Looking directly east from launch, there is a very large meadow in Bear Creek Park, this is suitable however the field is often full of Mullen. There is a smaller LZ meadow north of the big meadow, this is the preferred LZ. 

There appears to be a large LZ meadow just northeast of launch in the Red Rock Canyon Open Space. This is an old landfill and is strictly prohibited.

desc: Beach

name: South landing
desc: Straight in front of launch, just before the houses, visible from launch as a small, circular, bare patch. Has slight downhill slope to the south. Paraglider pilots should set up their approach so as to not overfly the wash to the west of the LZ and plan on landing short of the LZ to compensate for the famous South Mountain Pop. Much of the terrain around the LZ is usable for landing, just avoid getting popped and floating into or close to the houses.

name: Whale Hill LZ
desc:
Basically landing is possible everywhere; the indicated position is preferable, as there is less sage brush which can catch your lines. Beware of fences! If necessary, place a windsock when going up;
further out (east) some power lines...

name: Abernathy Creek LZ
desc: Slightly rolling Tundra 2820 MSL. Open

name: Tumwater Mountain LZ
desc:
There have been issues with land owners not wanting pilots to land in their yard, please pack up quickly and not hang out on private property.  The football field is now under construction as the school is building a new addition.

In grassy football field below and straight out from launch. Easy glide to get there with plenty of altitude.

name: Mt. Umunhum LZ
desc: There are lots of park areas nearby and potential landings, not sure yet where the approved LZ will be, but help us figure it out!

name: Grizzly Mountain LZ
desc: talk to landowners before landing there!

name: West Mountain (Payson) LZ
desc: diffrent possibilities around the mountain; given cordinates are for a place on the road to launch. Avoid landing in fields with cattle or sheep!

name: Crawford LZ
desc: The main landing area is on BLM land at the mouth of the canyon on the road up. Landing directly below launch there is a field with no fences to cross. Lots of landing areas in fields but avoid livestock and alfalfa and the ranchers a cool.

name: Goat Rock LZ
desc: Landing on the beach below is easy, but do not get anywhere near ocean.  5 minute walk back up for re-flights.  Also possible to top land.

name: Lee Vining LZ
desc:
landing on highschool playground only on Sundays!
But lots of other fields.

name: Mt Tom LZ
desc: Park here if you have a way up to the trail head. Otherwise, park up by the trail head.

name: Whitwell - Tennessee Tree Toppers LZ
desc: Traditional LZ is Castle's and is private property, so please be respectful. Church LZ not to be used on Sunday before Noon.

name: Main LZ
desc: Look for windsock

name: Snowbird LZ
Y Mountain LZ
desc:
Kiwanis Park is one mile due west from the Y at 820 N 1100 E Provo, UT.  Leave a car at the park beforehand and drive up to the Y trailhead parking lot to hike up to the launch site.

The abandoned fields between N Oakmont Lane and N Locust Lane just to the East of the park make a great landing zone as well but are privately owned by the University.  After a pilot treed his glider and the police and fire department were called, BYU doesn't want any more pilots landing there.

name: Hyner View LZ
desc:
41Â°19'16.42'N  77Â°38'5.51'W

Landing field is also club, please see website. It is a great big long field just across the river. Often can get a little turbulent in the afternoons. Plenty of room to make a nice long approach.

name: New landing for Woodstock
desc: The official landing is marked. Other landings only to be used in emergencies. Please see site guide for more information http://chgpa.org/weather-and-site-info/

name: Dirt road options
desc: Multiple landing options exist. The local favorite is top landing at the launch. If you must land out, there is a large amount of construction around the area, with large flat areas for landing. In general, dirt roads near the ridge seem to work best. There is also a gravel pit, option 2, which works well if you avoid the obvious obstacles there. Option 3 is a large grassy park/field, but it is upwind of the launch which makes it difficult to make it to. Expect to make it only if you have altitude.

name: Cleary Summit LZ
desc:
Parking area at bottom along side hwy.
or glide out over valley and land in the bottom if you don't mind a long hike out.

name: Blue Springs ridge LZ

name: Farleys (aka Grants East Ridge) LZ

POWERED PARAGLIDING & ULTRALITE
2500' Grass Runway

name: Big Walker LZ

name: The LZ

Beware of soccer days and events.

name: Beaver Creek Resort LZ
desc:
Area is presently C L O S E D !!!!
The landing zone is a short cross country flight to the north preferably to the midway section of the Beaver Creek Golf Course where free shuttles bring you back to the lifts.  Alternate landing areas include Beano's Cabin and areas near Avon, Colorado.

name: Sky Ranch LZ
desc: Several landing options, all of them a 5:1 glide or farther. The Sky Ranch LZ on a large, open river bar by Highway 299 and Sky Ranch Road (near Junction City) is a 5:1 glide but cannot be seen from the launch due to a ridge blocking the view. It is suitable for hang gliders and paragliders. Paraglider pilots can land along Weaver Bally Road in the burned out area about 1 mile up the road from Highway 299, also a 5:1 glide from launch. This is an unimproved landing zone with nearby terrain features and trees that make workable but less than ideal in wind or thermic conditions. Other options with further glides are available.

desc: Landing zone is either on the road at the base or on the side of the golf course. There is plenty of LZ space which makes this site suitable for beginners.

desc: Use main LZ, which is a far glide.  Requires you to soar to the north to establish requisite glide slope, otherwise use bailout LZ.

name: Bighorn Mountain launch LZ
desc: public land

name: LZ
desc:
All LZ's are unimproved, not flat and have large growths of sagebrush. Pilots are advised to walk the LZ 's before flight.
  The main landing zone has the largest gaps of open ground between sagebrush  growth. Located on the west side of the road, south of parking. 

 The north LZ  is across the road from the parking area. With good spot landing skills, it allows for landing  across from the parking area in west winds.

The cemetery landing zone is southeast of Morgan Cemetery. This LZ is intended for sledders and sinking out from the Upper Knob Launch. The LZ is mostly sage brush covered, and it may be difficult to land here without getting lines tangled in the sage. Notably, there is private land adjacent to this LZ without a visible indicator of the property line. The property line follows an imaginary line from the center of the Upper Knob Launch down to the intersection of Morgan Lane and Rocky Mountain Road.

name: Little Ellis LZ
desc: Land in the field west of the trailhead, across the first row of bushes, and away from the houses to the north. Be especially careful when horses are on the trail or at the house by the trailhead. Gliders approaching landing have previously spooked horses, endangering riders and angering nearby landowners.

name: Tierra Negra LZ
desc:
Former town site.  Gravel flat area.  Criscrossed with dead power lines, but can be easily avoided as the LZ is large.  

Approach is almost always from the North West.  Do not fly above the town of Las Gonzalez on the South side of the freeway.

name: Los caballos LZ

Reason why the thermals starts to pop up around 10am, allowing to XC for over 2hrs and up to 2500mts plus.  There are many alternative safe landing spots along the valley.

name: Military Training Field
desc: Strictly available to registered pilots only. Please contact the local clubs for permission. This is a very sensitive area.

name: Lions Head (Cape Town) LZ
desc:
Landing is on a grassy, shoreline cricket field next to La Med cafe at the Glen Country Club. The field is rented by the Camps Bay High School, so try to have a minimum impact on any sports being played on the field (it is a bit short for hang gliders). There is a sock at the far southwestern corner of the field, but at time of revision the sock in place was on the small side and bleached white by the sun. Aside from the sock, there are plenty of palm trees to watch for wind direction around the field, but no flags, banners or other indicators. 

The Camps Bay High School field (above the main road, to the left of the big swimming pool) can be used as an alternative if it is empty. 

During the summer season the Municipality has asked us to please avoid landing on the beaches (Camps Bay, Clifton, Glen). There is also a median strip between the upper main road and the lower main road, just above La Med. 

The lower slopes of Lion's Head can be used to slope-land in an emergency.
> Keep in mind that these slopes look deceptively shallow from the air; in truth, they're steeper than they look from above.

The hang-gliding alternative landing is Mouille Point lighthouse.

name: Dasklip Pass, Porterville LZ
desc:
At the bottom! You will see the 'Turkey Patch' when you get there, just where the road to launch splits off. There is a windsock at a fork with a few fields to choose from. If that windsock is pointing horizontally the launch is often blown out, beware.
I generally land on the far side of the road to avoid telephone lines and stuff like that. Don't land in crops and don't land in fields with ostriches they can get real nasty!!

name: SedgeField, Cloud Nine LZ
desc:
Top Landing possible, get a site briefing.
For students and low airtime pilots:
Large Grass field below ridge.
Official landing directly below launch with Yellow windsock. Please walk out to gate in the direction of the village.

name: Maitlands Bottom LZ
desc: Top landing on site not recommended due to road traffic. Land on beach next to car park .Keep beach goers in mind ,they dont always see you and also cant hear you.

name: Maitlands LZ
desc: On the beach next to car park.

name: Dunnottar LZ
desc: No trees but corn fields when in crop

name: Paradise Falls LZ
desc:
In front of take-off, grass field with a few tall trees, but enough space for students to land easily.
Watch out for powerlines, trees and donga at end of the field.
Also possible to land next to the main road if you can clear the trees - a good challenge for many students especially as a final flight at the end of the day.

name: Gods Window LZ
desc: Top, or far out in the valley below which is covered with pine/bluegum plantations! Make sure you have arrange recovery driver and describe the landing position before you lose radio contact in the wilderness :-)

name: Long Tom Pass LZ
